The ongoing conflict in Gaza has created a dire humanitarian crisis, particularly in the northern Gaza Strip, where displaced people are without medical services or humanitarian aid [24]. The Israeli Defense Forces (IDF) have intensified military operations in Rafah, responding to rocket and mortar fire by striking several sites with aircraft and engaging in close-quarters combat at the Rafah crossing [25]. These actions, along with evacuation orders, have severely disrupted humanitarian activities in Gaza [1]. As a result, approximately 50,000 people evacuated Rafah within 48 hours, and over 150,000 have fled in recent days [1][26][27]. Around 300,000 people are affected by these orders as the conflict in Rafah escalates [1][26][27]. Displaced Palestinians face horrific conditions, lacking adequate access to food, water, and other essentials [27]. Vulnerable groups, including malnourished infants, the elderly, and those with severe disabilities, are among those forced to move [27].

The closure of the Rafah crossing, a critical entry point for aid, has exacerbated the situation, cutting off access to fuel and essential supplies [7]. The UN agency for Palestinian refugees (UNRWA) reports that no aid or fuel has entered Gaza, which is disastrous for the humanitarian response [3]. Fuel stocks are critically low, with only 30,000 litres of diesel available, while 200,000 litres are needed daily [9][16][17]. The lack of fuel affects everything from food distribution to hospital operations and telecommunications [11]. Aid agencies are nearly out of food and fuel, with stocks depleting hourly [8][3]. The prioritization of remaining fuel for health, water, and communication services highlights the impact on daily life [9].

The UN Human Rights Chief, Volker Türk, has warned that Israel's evacuation orders in Rafah will increase civilian deaths and suffering, contravening international humanitarian and human rights laws [14]. Palestinians remaining in Rafah are at risk of death and injury from indiscriminate bombing and lack of access to essentials [15]. Türk emphasized the need for accountability for those disregarding international laws [15].

Despite a ceasefire proposal from Egypt and Qatar, which Hamas accepted, Israel's rejection of the proposal has dashed hopes for peace [19][2]. Israeli forces have seized the Rafah crossing, further complicating aid delivery [19][5]. The ongoing military operations have made the crossing an active war zone, preventing the entry of aid and fuel [2][3]. The situation remains fluid, with no safe zones in Gaza, and designated evacuation sites like Al-Mawasi are overstretched and unsafe [17][3].

The conflict has severely hindered humanitarian efforts, with no aid trucks entering since May 5 [6]. The closure of crossings has led to increased hunger and scarcity, as well as fear and confusion among civilians [7][20]. The UN Secretary-General has called for political courage from both Hamas and Israel to secure a ceasefire [28]. However, the main obstacles include Israel's rejection of proposals that do not meet its core demands and its goal to destroy Hamas [29][30][31]. The humanitarian crisis in Gaza continues to worsen, with no immediate resolution in sight.

These are not safe places.I have repeatedly expressed my alarm about the catastrophic impact of a possible full-scale offensive on Rafah, including the possibility of further atrocity crimes. I can see no way that the latest evacuation orders, much less a full assault, in an area with an extremely dense presence of civilians, can be reconciled with the binding requirements of international humanitarian law and with the two sets of binding provisional measures ordered by the International Court of Justice.At this desperate moment, exacerbated by acts impeding the entry of humanitarian aid in Gaza through the three crossings, there is a dire shortage of fuel, which is hindering everything  from the movement to distribution of food, operation of hospitals and emergency services, sewage treatment and telecommunications.
11.title: Comment by UN High Commissioner for Human Rights Volker Türk on Gaza (12 May 2024)

18.context: No alternative plan has been presented for how aid will be able to enter, and certainly not at the levels needed, if these crossings are disrupted.Rafah's main hospital, the Abu Yousuf Najjar Hospital, which is currently only partially functioning, is also in the areas ordered to evacuate. Patients and healthcare workers forced to leave must be urgently protected.The international community knows that this invasion will be a catastrophe. The killing of civilians will accelerate and much more of Gaza's remaining infrastructure will be destroyed. The meagre humanitarian aid reaching people will be severely disrupted, just days after the head of the World Food Programme assessed that northern Gaza is experiencing "full blown famine" that is "moving its way south".The UK and other governments allied with Israel must work urgently to stop this assault from going ahead, avert a further humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza and attain a permanent ceasefire.
18.title: MAP demands urgent action to halt Rafah offensive and avert further humanitarian catastrophe
